result.execSummary:
The defendant Kevin B McHenry was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • OWI Cause Injury (2+), a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 346.63(2)(a)1.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Provide DNA sample.
Defendant is advised:   he is a convicted felon and may not possess any firearms; and that he is unable to vote in any election until civil rights are restored.

No possession/consumption/selling/distribution of ilegal drugs/alcohol.
No alcohol or drugs.
Follow all rules of supervision.  Follow through with any other treatment deemed necessary by the department.
AODA assessment. Cooperate with any programs deemed necessary by the probation department.  Absolute/maintain sobriety.  Random urine screens.

All court costs, fees and surcharges including DNA.
IF REVOKED:  all court costs, surcharges and restitution to be paid through collection by DOC from 25% of funds under Sec. 973.05(4)(b) and as a condition of Extended supervision.  DOC shall collect those sums. Any amount remaining due and owing is subject to civil judgment and/or tax intercept or other means.

Letter filed by Eisenberg, Riley & Zimmerman, S.C.

Defendant Kevin B McHenry in court with attorney John Kenyatta Riley.  Thomas L. Potter appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Sentencing proceeded.  Statements by the State, defense and defendant. 

The Court sentenced the defendant to a MAXIMUM TERM OF IMPRISONMENT of  4 YEARS with 2 days credit CONSECUTIVE to any other sentence; the INITIAL TERM OF CONFINEMENT in the Wisconsin State Prison System is 2 YEARS; the MAXIMUM TERM OF EXTENDED SUPERVISION is 2 YEARS.

Court finds defendant IS eligible for the Challenge Incarceration program and the Earned Release program.  

Court STAYED the sentence and placed the defendant on 3 YEARS probation.  Conditions of Probation/ Extended Supervision if revoked:
- 1 YEAR condition time in the House of Corrections.  1st six months with Huber for work, 2nd six months with electronic monitoring.
- AODA assessment and cooperate with any programs deemed necessary by the probation department.
- Absolute/maintain sobriety, no alcohol, no drugs.
- No possession/consumption/selling/distribution of illegal drugs/alcohol.
- Random urine screens.
- Provide a DNA sample.
- Follow all rules of supervision and follow through with any other treatment deemed necessary by the department.

Court ordered the defendant pay all of the following by the end of supervision.  Failure to pay will result in a civil judgment:
Restitution in the amount of $6,237.96 payable to Lamont D by either the defendant or his insurance company; 
All court costs, fees, and surcharges (including DNA); 
All applicable fees of supervision.
-  No Cash Bail Posted in this matter. 
-  Court approves payment plan to agent discretion.
-  If revoked, the Court ordered that all court costs, fines, surcharges and/or restitution be paid through collection by the Department of Corrections from 25% of funds under Sec. 973.05(4)(b) and as a condition of extended supervision. DOC shall collect those sums.  Any amount remaining due and owing is subject to civil judgment and/or tax intercept or other means.

Court ordered defendant's operating privileges revoked for 12 months with the mandatory reinstatement fee.  

Defendant's operating privilege for operation of Class D vehicles is restricted to operating vehicles that are equipped with an ignition interlock device; and each motor vehicle for which the defendant's name appears on the vehicle's certificate of title or registration must be equipped with an ignition interlock device beginning on the date the department issues any license and for a period of 12 months thereafter.


Court advised defendant that as a convicted felon he may never possess a firearm. 
Court advised defendant of his right to seek postconviction relief.
Court advised defendant that hemay not vote until his civil rights have been restored.

Court stayed commencement until 09/05/2014 at 5:00pm.  Failure to report will result in revocation of probation.
WCS Intoxicated Driver Intervention program report, recevied and filed.

Defendant Kevin B McHenry in court with attorney John K Riley.  Thomas L Potter appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Defendant changes plea to NO CONTEST. Defendant examined as to his plea, advised of his Constitutional rights and the maximum penalty. Court found that defendant freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived his rights. Plea questionnaire received and filed. Parties stipulate to the complaint as a factual basis to sustain defendant's plea. Court found defendant guilty as charged in the information and ordered a Judgment of Conviction be entered on the record. Defendant is advised he is a convicted felon and may not possess any firearms. Defendant is advised he is unable to vote in any election until civil rights are restored. Defendant further advised that if he is not a US citizen deportation is possible.  PSI was NOT ordered. Case set for sentencing in Branch 22.
Sentencing hearing scheduled for 09-02-2014 at 08:30 am.
